Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Direct Optical Lithography of Functional Inorganic Nanomaterials
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the opportunity to reduce current energy consumption in existing displays (e.g. TVs, outdoor signage, mobile phones, wearables, AR/VR) in the United States by 70% while simultaneously improving color experience by 50%.

The Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will investigate the engineering parameters and the reliability of the core technology for commercialization. The core technology is a suite of ligand chemistries that enable virtually any functional nanoparticles to be turned into an ink for patterning of next generation electronics such as displays. Unlike any other technology, the final film, can pattern extremely dense films with over 90% loading of nanoparticles. When the technology is applied to quantum dots and displays, the resulting device is 70% more energy-efficient while simultaneously 50% better in color experience. The Phase I project research objective is to identify the ink formulation comprising of our technology that is compatible with at-scale manufacturing equipment. Variables such as viscosity, solvent composition, and shelf life will be investigated.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Displays are everywhere, yet the performance of these displays still leave much to be desired. TVs today are energy inefficient; your smartphone needs to be charged every night; it is hard to see your screen in the sun; and you can get nauseous from extended use of Augmented and Virtual Reality headsets (i.e. AR/VR sickness). Fortunately, there have been leaps in display technologies in the last decade as Organic LED (OLED) and microLED displays have started to replace the ever-dominant Liquid Crystal Displays (LCDs). MicroLED displays are particularly interesting because they can address all the unmet needs of current generation displays. With microLED displays: your TV would triple in energy efficiency; your smartphone would go days with a single charge; phone screens would be easily seen outdoors; and AR/VR sickness would not be an issue. Unfortunately, the best microLED displays are available only as single color (i.e. blue or green), limiting applications to non-consumer displays. Current methods for enabling tricolor microLED displays which can show full red, green, and blue color have 1) limited resolution, 2) require the purchase of expensive and untested manufacturing equipment, and 3) are made using low throughput techniques.

Through the support of the NSF SBIR Phase I grant ? NanoPattern Technologies, Inc. successfully derisked the recipe for an ink that enables the manufacturing of tricolor microLED displays using existing manufacturing techniques. Figure 1 shows green pixels patterned with the NanoPattern ink, while Red and blue pixels have also been demonstrated. As can be seen from the image scale, these pixels are patterned at 5 micrometer by 5 micrometer resolutions. Such resolutions are needed for the precise applications in wearables and VR/AR headsets. We also project that the resolution can be pushed even higher. Currently, the closest competitor can achieve 20 micrometer by 20 micrometer resolutions, limiting applications to larger format displays. With the risks addressed, NanoPattern can now move towards developing the ink product in partnership with large chemical companies for global distribution. The resulting benefit to the consumer is a new generation of consumer electronics (i.e. TVs, monitors, smartphones, wearables, VR/AR headsets) with better energy efficiency, better color purity for crisper images, and no nausea during extended use of VR/AR headsets.
